claim:
Consider the following background information: A 19-year-old woman is brought into the emergency department after collapsing during a cheerleading practice session. Her vitals taken by the emergency medical services (EMS) include blood pressure 88/55 mm Hg, pulse 55/min. She was given a liter of isotonic fluid while en route to the hospital. At the emergency department, she is alert and oriented and is noted to be anorexic. The patient fervently denies being underweight claiming that she is ‘a fatty’ and goes on to refuse any further intravenous fluid and later, even the hospital meals.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: Cognitive-behavioral therapy is the best option for long-term management of this patient"s condition.

supporting.text: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is evidence-based for treating eating disorders by addressing distorted self-perception and maladaptive behaviors.

attacks.text: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is evidence-based for treating eating disorders by addressing distorted self-perception and maladaptive behaviors.
CBT may not be effective if the patient lacks insight or refuses to acknowledge their condition, as seen in this case.
Even resistant patients can benefit from CBT over time, as it is designed to gradually modify cognitive distortions.
Medical stabilization and nutritional rehabilitation should take priority over CBT in severely malnourished patients.
CBT can be integrated with medical treatment to address both physical and psychological aspects simultaneously.

supporting.text: The patient's denial of being underweight and refusal of treatment align with anorexia nervosa, where CBT is a first-line intervention.

attacks.text: The patient's denial of being underweight and refusal of treatment align with anorexia nervosa, where CBT is a first-line intervention.
CBT may not be effective if the patient lacks insight or refuses to engage in therapy, which is common in severe anorexia nervosa cases.
Family-based therapy (FBT) has shown higher efficacy than CBT in adolescents and young adults with anorexia nervosa, especially when the patient is resistant to treatment.
The patient's acute medical instability (e.g., low blood pressure and pulse) requires immediate medical intervention before psychological therapies like CBT can be effective.
Integrated treatment plans combining medical stabilization with CBT have demonstrated better long-term outcomes than standalone CBT in severely malnourished patients.

supporting.text: Long-term management of eating disorders requires psychological therapy like CBT to prevent relapse and promote healthy behaviors.

attacks.text: Long-term management of eating disorders requires psychological therapy like CBT to prevent relapse and promote healthy behaviors.
CBT may not be effective for all patients with eating disorders, especially those with severe malnutrition or comorbid psychiatric conditions.
Studies show that CBT has the highest efficacy among psychological therapies for eating disorders, even in severe cases, when combined with medical stabilization.
Family-based therapy (FBT) has shown better long-term outcomes than CBT for adolescent patients with eating disorders.
FBT is primarily effective for younger adolescents, while CBT remains the gold standard for adults and older adolescents like this 19-year-old patient.
The patient's refusal of treatment suggests poor insight, which may limit the effectiveness of CBT as it requires active patient participation.
Motivational enhancement techniques can be integrated with CBT to improve engagement in patients with poor insight.

supporting.text: CBT has been shown to improve outcomes in anorexia nervosa by targeting cognitive distortions and eating habits.

attacks.text: CBT has been shown to improve outcomes in anorexia nervosa by targeting cognitive distortions and eating habits.
CBT may not be effective if the patient is unwilling to acknowledge their condition or engage in therapy, as seen in this case where the patient denies being underweight.
Even resistant patients can benefit from CBT over time, as therapeutic engagement often improves with persistent, empathetic intervention.
Severe malnutrition in anorexia nervosa may require medical stabilization (e.g., refeeding, electrolyte correction) before CBT can be effectively implemented.
CBT can be adapted to run concurrently with medical stabilization, addressing psychological barriers to treatment adherence early.

supporting.text: Medical stabilization alone is insufficient for anorexia nervosa; CBT addresses the underlying psychological factors.

attacks.text: Medical stabilization alone is insufficient for anorexia nervosa; CBT addresses the underlying psychological factors.
CBT may not be effective for all patients with anorexia nervosa, as individual responses to therapy vary widely.
Studies show that CBT has a higher success rate compared to other therapies for anorexia nervosa, especially when combined with medical treatment.
Family-based therapy (FBT) has been shown to be more effective than CBT for adolescents and young adults with anorexia nervosa.
FBT may not be suitable for all patients, especially those who are older or have strained family relationships.

supporting.text: The patient's symptoms and refusal of care suggest a need for structured psychotherapy like CBT to ensure recovery.

attacks.text: The patient's symptoms and refusal of care suggest a need for structured psychotherapy like CBT to ensure recovery.
CBT may not address the immediate medical risks of severe malnutrition and electrolyte imbalances in this patient.
Medical stabilization and nutritional rehabilitation should precede psychotherapy to ensure the patient is physically stable.
The patient's denial of being underweight indicates anosognosia, which may limit the effectiveness of CBT.
Specialized therapies like Maudsley Family Therapy may be more effective for patients with severe eating disorders and denial.
